Random Forest

Source: vignettes/random-forest.Rmd
random-forest.Rmd

Load packages and data 

library(tiDML)
library(tiDML)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(recipes)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'recipes'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     step
library(parsnip)

Random forest with default settings 

df <- diamonds_sample(n=500)

fit_rf <- dml_rf(
  data = df,
  y = "price",
  d = "is_rated_ideal",
  x = c("carat", "depth", "table", "x", "y", "z"),
)

tidy(fit_rf)
#> # A tibble: 1 × 6
#>   term               estimate std.error conf.low conf.high vcov_type
#>   <chr>                 <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    
#> 1 is_rated_idealTRUE     149.      165.    -174.      472. HC2

Random Forest with custom settings

You can also customise the default dml_rf() to some degree. Here I set a custom grid of number of trees to try during hyperparameter tuning (NB this tests 100 and 200, rather than everything in between). You can also set the number of folds for cross-fitting and the type of robust standard errors to use (choice of “HC0”, “HC1”, “HC2”, “HC3”, or “HC4”).

fit_rf <- dml_rf(
  data = df,
  y = "price",
  d = "is_rated_ideal",
  x = c("carat", "depth", "table", "x", "y", "z"),
  n_folds = 5,
  n_rep = 3,
  vcov_type = "HC2",
  trees_grid = c(100, 200))

tidy(fit_rf)
#> # A tibble: 1 × 6
#>   term               estimate std.error conf.low conf.high vcov_type
#>   <chr>                 <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    
#> 1 is_rated_idealTRUE     187.      154.    -114.      487. HC2
